intro: Antillanthus moaensis, commonly known as the Moa Island hibiscus, is a flowering plant native to the island of Moa in the Caribbean. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton plants. The plant is characterized by its showy, trumpet-shaped flowers that are typically pink or red in color. It thrives in coastal areas and is adapted to saline and wind-exposed environments. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a rare and endangered species.
